Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a BioMark HD System for single-cell genomics research.
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to The University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA) to purchase the BioMark HD/C1 System (Fluidigm), a multi-mode instrument for high-throughput single-cell sample preparation, real-time PCR (qPCR), end-point PCR, and digital PCR that enables gene expression analyses (including on single cells), genotyping and absolute copy number determination. This instrument addresses a major limitation of contemporary biological research by permitting molecular experiments at the level of individual cells, which may differ within a population. By permitting single-cell analyses, this instrument enables novel experiments that would otherwise be essentially impossible to pursue. The BioMark HD/C1 system combines high-throughput nanofluidics with quantitative PCR to measure the expression of hundreds of genes or gene sequence variations in hundreds of individual cells or samples in just a few hours. Investigators Brian Hermann, Rena Bizios, J. Aaron Cassill, Garry Sunter and colleagues from multiple departments (Biology, Chemistry, Biomedical Engineering) within two colleges (Sciences, Engineering) at UTSA and around San Antonio will utilize this unique instrument to investigate basic biological questions in broad topic areas including germ cell biology, neurobiology, cellular biophysics, plant virus host defense, plant herbivore defense, and insect olfaction. This instrument will be established as a core resource for research and research training at UTSA and the San Antonio area.

Acquisition of the BioMark HD/C1 System at UTSA through the Major Research Instrumentation program will provide scientists and students at all levels (high-school, undergraduate and graduate students) with access to a cutting-edge scientific instrument for research and training. This instrumentation will enhance the research environment at UTSA and provide opportunities for training students and postdoctoral fellows to become productive researchers. Since UTSA is a designated Hispanic-serving institution, this award will broaden participation of underrepresented groups at all levels. Indeed, the BioMark HD/C1 system will be utilized by students in several educational programs at UTSA that are specifically designed to attract and retain students from underrepresented groups to scientific research and promote their interest in pursuing research careers. This instrument will provide trainees with relevant experience using cutting edge technology, which will pique their interest in research and maximize their marketability for careers in academic and industrial science. Training in the use of the BioMark HD/C1 instrument will also be integrated with existing teaching and outreach programs to promote use of high-tech instrumentation in a manner that integrates training with real-world experimentation and discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was to purchase the BioMark HD/C1 System (Fluidigm) to support single-cell genomics research and training at the University of Texas at San Antonio. This instrumentation was needed in order to address a major need for experiments in biology and related disciplines in which scientists examine individual cells at the level of genetic molecules (RNA and DNA) within complex groups of cells. A key challenge to this type of research is that when examining groups of cells, if the members of the groups (that is, the individual cells) do not behave the same, then the results of the experiments will reflect the average of the group, rather than what each individual cell is doing. Therefore, in order to study biological phenomena in which differences between individual cells plays an important role, we need to be able to look at the individual cells. Until very recently, this was impossible to do. The instrument system we purchased allows scientists to study the expression of hundreds of genes or gene sequence variations (up to all of the genes in a cell) in hundreds of individual cells or samples in a few hours. This reflects a giant leap forward in terms of sensitivity and utility of the results of experiments.

 

At UTSA, the BioMark HD/C1 instruments were installed in Late 2013 and have been continually operating ever since. Consequently, this allowed UTSA to begin offering single-cell genomics services in a core facility for research and education to benefit members of the UTSA research community and scientists throughout San Antonio and the South Texas region. In addition, we hired a new full-time Genomics Core Manager to operate the equipment and trained an educator to operate the equipment for educational purposes. We also developed a training experiment which would allow the instruments to be used by students in their educational programs. Since the BioMark HD/C1 system was purchased with this NSF MRI grant, the equipment has enabled experiments for 8 different investigators in basic biology, biomedical engineering, and translational science and we anticipate usage to continue growing.

 

Results of experiments that used these instruments have already contributed data to four scientific publications, at least two more that are being prepared, and 12 abstracts that have or will be presented at national/international scientific research meetings. The types of studies that have utilized this unique system are very broad, touching on basic biology of germ cells that make sperm, brain cells, plant defenses against viruses, parasites, and bone engineering. In all cases, the BioMark HD/C1 system has already allowed studies to be performed that would otherwise be impossible to pursue. As an example, a series of experiments were done with male germ cells that will become sperm in order to identify the key features of those cells which have evolved to allow for sperm production. The results of those experiments have implication for agriculture, endangered species conservation, and male fertility. Other results have implications for engineering of bone replacements and understanding how nerve cells in the brain that produce a chemical called dopamine function. In addition, a quite surprising outcome of this award is that faculty researchers in the UTSA College of Business and UTSA College of Engineering are using the special data produced by these instruments to learn more about statistics and data modeling of complex systems. Lastly, a number of people have been trained to perform this high-tech work, which provides them with unique experience that will benefit their future careers in science and engineering. In particular, 16 research trainees and technical staff received hands-on experience with the instruments or the specialized data generated by the instruments, including 11 women and 2 trainees from minority groups. One college student who learned how to use the instruments and published her results went on to successfully compete for a prestigious NSF Graduate Research Fellowship and is now pursuing a PhD in Biomedical Engineering. Ultimately, we expect that the instruments purchased with these NSF funds will continue to allow future experiments to be performed and more scientists to be trained in the cutting-edge technology.
